title: Have you ever changed someone's mind on a major political topic and how did you do it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hmmm. Maybe sort of kind of my boyfriend? When we met he had voted for Mitt Romney and I had voted for Barack Obama, so our votes had cancelled out. Anyway, he’s very much a traditional Republican. He’s a conservative, traditional dude on the whole. ESPECIALLY economically. He has his undergrad degree in business, so he pays special attention to the economy and the stock market. He even reads books on the latter. I’m good with economics but idk about the stock market too super much other than how basic economics applies to it. Over the years, and really when I had learned about it more, I asked his opinions on things like abortion rights or voter oppression. He really didn’t have an opinion. So I gave him both sides (I used Marilyn Frye and Judith Jarvis for pro choice and Marquis for pro life) and asked him questions about whatever side he had taken (I was taking bioethics at the time so this helped). I guess he isn’t too much of a traditional guy (although I consider him traditional because he’s into stuff like marriage and traditional gender roles…for example…I cook and clean and, um, do all the manual labor so I guess he’s also selectively traditional LOL) because he’s very laid back and is just all, “Do what you want” on social issues. So he turned out to be pretty liberal on social issues. He’s pro choice because he says he would have no idea what it’s like to be in a woman’s position like that. He’s Jewish so he has no religious incentive to oppose abortion; he’s actually atheist (a position I’ve tried to convince him out of…) so religion isn’t a Thing for him. He didn’t like voter suppression or banning non-White immigrants either because he felt that was similar to discrimination against Jews. Now, on the national debt. I couldn’t get him to budge an inch for, what, 3–4 years? He’s a hawk on it. Honestly, what really “flipped” him was this current GOP administration. He’s a tax lawyer and so has written summaries of the tax bill — and read the entire bill in full to do so — for a tax law blog his firm runs and he writes for. First off, he was disappointed with the initial presentation — sloppy and written notes in the margins. He’s a meticulous guy and scored well/placed in the top 10 in law school and top 10 in his LLM program (like a masters in tax after law school and after you take the Bar) by paying close attention to detail. He’s a master at grammar and number stuff/corporate restructuring. He loves that stuff and takes a lot of pride in the thoroughness of his work. He said he would not turn in what they introduced to the floor for a law school/LLM assignment. Besides that, he says it’s truly pretty mediocre, charitably, or bad in uncharitable terms regarding benefit to the middle class and that the GOP is hyping it up way too much (ie how good it is for regular people). And their rhetoric is disingenuous. He can’t help but comment whenever they mention it and say, “Well you could put it that way..*roll eyes*” I think it really bothers him the GOP thinks people are that gullible on a wide array of issues (not just the tax bill but things like “trickle down” economics). I have no idea, myself, because I haven’t read the bill and don’t know those issues particularly well. I’m more into health issues and women’s issues. That alone, paired with Trump’s general way of conducting himself and a lot of his very blatant lying, bothered him enough to write into the Supervisor of Elections and change his party to Democrat without me saying anything. One day I came home and he said, “I wrote in. I am so embarrassed to be associated with that now.” The boyfriend is not so much of a hawk anymore; he also believes in free trade after seeing how much extreme isolationist talk has has gone on. That was the last domino to fall in his conservative stance. I think he’s safely a neo-Liberal. I don’t think he will ever be as liberal or into activism as me because the clients he deals with in his work are multi-millionaires and, sometimes, billionaires. With my experience in social work and healthcare disparities I can’t pull my focus away from those populations in good faith with my political positions. Oh, I also changed my sister’s mind after showing her the BBC and the regulations associated with its reporting. She was dating this emotionally abusive, sexist asshole who watched one of those crazy YouTube republican guys as news (oh yeah his name was Alex Jones on Youtube). So she had no idea Pizzagate was completely false. It was scary because my sister is a smart woman, but somehow she was like, “No, Hillary Clinton sexually abused children on an island made for millionaires.” ← direct quote. I snapped her back in maybe 30–60 minutes though. I was like, “Why would the whole world be lying to you and Tony (her ex) telling you the truth? Why have you watched cable news and regular national news your whole life, that news has been accurate, and now it’s a bad, untrustworthy thing? Think for yourself.” Though I had pushback on other Trump stuff for at least 2 months after. She started reading “fake news”/mainstream media again and, 6 months into his presidency said, “Can you believe our president was bragging about grabbing someone by the pussy?!” And I said, “Yeah dude that came out before the election…..” she still said, about his many accusations of sexual misconduct, “Well just because he’s been accused doesn’t mean he did it.” Oh, but Clinton is running an illegal child sex trafficking ring?…I pushed her, “Out of all those allegations, what is the likelihood that at least one is true? And seeing how there are so many, that at least 2–6 are true?” My grandma will go to her grave believing Barack Obama is a terrorist Muslim who had Howard University cover up his false US citizenship. Eh, guess you can’t save em all. My mom is 75–80% sure Obama is a robot and/or a Muslim terrorist. I’ve heard her mention both. But I can only do so much.

I change people minds very often (whether or not they’ll admit it out loud is their issue). My education in Geography and Ethics/Philosophy is what gives me an edge. I really like to see fascist idiots look even worse, with egg on their face, after I gave them a dose of ‘the truth’ along with their own vile medicine. I basically mirror their patronizing behavior and replace gaslighting with cold, hard, unadulterated, facts. I treat them almost exactly how they’d treat me, except I don’t lie. I’ve never lost an argument, and I always get at least one concession and a hand shake at the end (they are complete idiots).

Yes, my own, on two topics. Firstly when I registered to vote at age 18 I was a staunch libertarian because I’d been reading Ayn Rand since I was 16. I believed in economic laissez-faire freedom at all costs, and voluntaryism. I.e. “If you don’t feel like paying for paved roads, public libraries, or a police department, because you don’t care about those things or are opposed to them, you shouldn’t be made to pay for them. Total freedom at all costs.” Then I got older and realized infrastructure is important and makes for a better society for everyone, and just because your neighbor is a selfish dick doesn’t mean you should suffer for it. Secondly, I used to be against abortion AND capital punishment when I was under 19, because I believed “every life is sacred”. Now, 20 years later, I’m all like “WTF was I thinking?” My perspective is that 1) no life is “sacred” because there’s no such thing as “sacred”, and 2) a human embryo has the same sentience as an oyster, and I sure did eat a lot of oysters back in those days with impunity (and still do.) Human embryos and first-trimester fetuses are way less sentient and sapient than most of the animals we consume as food. Sure, the fetus could grow up to be Einstein or Mother Teresa, but it could also grow up to be Hitler or Charles Manson. It’s better to terminate early-term pregnancies with severe congenital defects or risk factors, or ones with severely underprivileged, unwilling or unable parents. The world has enough kids, and there are already enough kids suffering in the foster care and orphanage systems, waiting, hoping and praying for adoption. We don’t need to create more kids born to terrible circumstances. I’m also neither here nor there about capital punishment anymore, providing it’s humanely done (lethal injection is VERY CONTROVERSIAL because some studies have shown that roughly half of the time the person actually dies in excruciating pain; please look it up.) If it’s actually humane and the person is incontrovertibly guilty, and a likely permanent danger to society regardless of psychiatric treatment, and has sincerely confessed under no duress, it’s certainly a better option for the person instead of having to suffer for decades longer in a supermax prison, and it would also be more affordable for the public. Besides, we all die in the end, and 100 years from now no one will remember us. You can sum up my current worldview this way: I’m all about minimizing suffering. I’m no longer registered as a libertarian. Haven’t been since my mid-20s, when the US Libertarian party became nothing more than a bunch of alternatively-named Tea Partiers, a much-crazier version of Republicans, who just didn’t want to pay any taxes or have any immigrants in our country and wanted to own grenade launchers at will. It became literally the opposite of what I stood for. I don’t know that I align with any particular party anymore. I just have my own opinions on individual issues. When I take political alignment tests I always score as an extreme left-libertarian, i.e. an extreme democratic socialist. So I’m usually registered with the Greens, except during presidential primaries season, when I temporarily switch my registration to Democrat so I can vote in a primary that matters. But none of these parties are fully in sync with my worldview.

Let me give you some facts First: you cannot change anyone else. Secondly: The only person you can change is you. Third, because you mentioned politics: Political beliefs are not generally based on rational thought, and thus do not generally respond well to any kind of arguments, discussion, rational discourse, or whatever. If Jesus Christ were to arrive, and told your friend to change his political views, your friend would find a way to ignore the advice. Here's what you CAN DO. Revise your own attitude towards your friend's views. A lot of people have friends who have different points of view. They simply agree to accept their friend as he is, and avoid discussion of topics that upset one or the other of you. This is why in many social clubs, religion and politics are out of bounds for discussion topics. If you were able to make such a strong and solid argument that you won the argument totally with your friend, you would still lose. You want to bring him to your side and gain another supporter for your side, but that won't happen; all you will accomplish for your efforts will be that you lose your friend!

Have you ever changed someone's mind on a major political topic and how did you do it? Can I claim myself? I changed my own mind on capital punishment after finding out how many people have been found to be innocent after being executed. I don’t find any percentage of innocent people being euthanized acceptable in pursuit of justice. In fact the very idea is an oxymoron. I have no problem with killing people guilty of all kinds of things. In fact my list is longer than the governments, and includes violent rape and child molestation, but it is far too difficult to KNOW who is guilty. The preponderance of evidence and reasonable doubt are good enough to free or incarcerate a person, but very little of what we accept as proof is good enough to end a life.

Yes. During Desert Storm, my sister was being a neo-hippy liberal, protesting against it and being a general pain in the ass. I tried to point out to her all of the crimes Saddam Hussein was committing against everyone in the region. She wouldn’t listen. I asked her “What if it was me, or Dad, or Uncle Mike over there?” She didn't care. Then I showed her the news footage of our pilots, brutally beaten and tortured. She changed her tune right quick then!

Hi Emily, Why would I want to control another awareness, it is not my or your task to change anyone nor their opinion. I can throw up a ball and it is up to the other person to catch it or not. He or she can throw up a ball and it is up to you when you want to catch it or not. Treat others, like you want to be treated. You can just inform what you have researched or observed and inform that person about it and ask questions about it. You have to leave the decision always to another person and give them space and time, even when you don’t agree or even when they make a mistake. This is proper communication. You always stay calm, composed, balanced and positive. A good tip besides above how to act in a discussion. Try to step also in the shoes of the other person and try to understand fully how they came to their conclusions. So you understand that person completely and you will know the right words to say. Still it is up to that person to decide what to believe or to do. Again, give them time and space, sometimes silence is golden. With best regards, Thomas Francisco Pelgero

I won’t name any names, but I’ve had several people on Quora tell me that they have reconsidered their views about certain matters after reading my Quora answers. Not all of them changed their minds, but many at least said they could better understand the other side’s perspective after reading my views, and that’s a good thing in my book. Even if we don’t agree, when people on opposite sides of the political spectrum can at least understand the other point of view, there’s a chance for compromise.

This isn’t a 100% guaranteed process, but it will at least create an environment for an open dialog. Which is the start to changing anyone’s mind.Create an open mind. (This includes both you and the other person. For you this means being open to being wrong about some things and the next steps will help open the other person’s mind.)Actively listen. (Hear the other person through without thinking of rebuttals.)Refrain from inflammatory language. (Use words with neutral emotional context.)Agree with what you do agree with-even if it is only on minor points. (Hey, everybody has a point about some part of what they believe. That is to say an actual reason that is actually reasonable.)Thank them for being so open as to share their thoughts with you so fully. (This makes them feel appreciated and heard if not understood.)Get their permission to state your case, noting you listened without interrupting and ask the same courtesy. (This creates an sort of internal obligation to reciprocate in most folks.)State your own case citing evidence and logic used to arrive at your conclusions. (Again use neutral language.)

I was talking to a fellow who seemed to believe that the entire difference between the intentional homicide rate in the US and Western Europe was due to the prevalence of guns in the US. I pointed out that the non-gun related homicide rate in the US was higher than the total homicide rate for just about all of the countries he was pointing to. I don’t think he did a complete 180 on his position, but at least he seemed to get to the point where he accepted that other factors were at play besides just guns.
